In my early days, I got rejected by every single company I applied to üòûüíî
All because of this one simple mistake:

üî¥ Jumping straight into code.
I‚Äôd miss edge cases, pick the wrong approach‚Ä¶
Here‚Äôs the framework that finally helped me crack coding interviews:

üìå Minute 1-2: Clarify the problem
Ask for edge cases, input/output expectations, constraints.
üìå Minute 3-5: Walk through examples
Pick a small input and dry-run it. Think out loud. Build trust.
üìå Minute 6-8: Talk brute force
Even if it‚Äôs not optimal, start somewhere. Thinking matters more than the final answer.
üìå Minute 9-10: Ask: ‚ÄúCan I start coding?‚Äù
Let the interviewer know your plan. Be collaborative, not silent.

Now, just knowing this framework isn‚Äôt enough. You need to practice it regularly to structure your thoughts and stay calm during the follow-ups. Mock interviews helped me develop that skill. ‚úîÔ∏è

If I had to start DSA from scratch in 2025, here‚Äôs the exact roadmap I‚Äôd follow:

üí°Start with any Language - C++, Java, or Python ‚Äî doesn't matter. Learn basics and start solving.

üìÖ Week 1‚Äì2: Arrays & Strings
Sliding Window, Two Pointers, Prefix Sum, Binary Search on Arrays, Sorting, Greedy Techniques

üìÖ Week 2‚Äì3: Linked Lists
Fast & Slow Pointers, Pointer Manipulation, Dummy Nodes, Cycle Detection (Floyd‚Äôs), In-place Reversal

üìÖ Week 3: Stacks & Queues
Monotonic Stack/Queue, Infix ‚Üí Postfix Conversion, Stack Simulation, LRU Logic, Circular Queue Techniques

üìÖ Week 4: Heaps & Priority Queues
Min/Max Heaps, Heapify Logic, Custom Comparators, Greedy with Heaps, Multi-way Merge

üìÖ Week 5‚Äì6: Trees & Graphs
Trees: DFS, BFS Traversals, Recursion on Trees, Lowest Common Ancestor, Depth, Height, Diameter, Binary Search Tree (BST) Ops
Graphs: Adjacency List/Matrix, DFS, BFS, Topological Sort, Union-Find (DSU), Dijkstra, Prim (Basics)

üìÖ Week 7: Recursion & Backtracking
Subset Generation, Permutations & Combinations, Maze & Grid Pathfinding, Decision Trees, State Tracking & Restoration

üìÖ Week 8: Dynamic Programming
Memoization & Tabulation, 1D, 2D, and Space Optimized DP, State Transition Formulas, DP with Choices, DP on Subsequences, Grids, Trees

üìÖ Week 9: Tries & Advanced Strings
Trie Construction, Prefix Matching, Pattern Searching (KMP, Z Algo), String Hashing, Suffix Arrays & Bit Tricks (optional)

üéØ Afterwards:
Pick a DSA Sheet (Striver, NeetCode, Babbar), Solve 1‚Äì2 problems daily, Participate in weekly contests

1Ô∏è‚É£ Tailor it to the Job Description
Don‚Äôt use one generic resume. Highlight relevant skills for each role.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Use action-oriented language
Words like Built, Designed, Reduced show initiative and ownership.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Show impact
Focus on outcomes, not just responsibilities. ‚Üí "Reduced query time by 40%" > "Worked on database."

4Ô∏è‚É£ Quantify wherever possible
Numbers help you stand out immediately.

5Ô∏è‚É£ Keep it clean & short

6Ô∏è‚É£ Make your work clickable
